  1. Introduction

    Java Network Programming

    Java supports transport layer (TCP/UDP) and above layer's programming. IP layer and MAC layer will need 3rd party libraries.

    java.net package provides networking programming functionilities.

  2. TCP

    TCP: Server-side

    1. ServerSocket: binding to a network interface, a port, and a maximum number of connection
    2. ServerSocket object accepts accept() connection, returns a socket object.The "delegate" socket has the same port number of the ServerSocket.
    3. Get Input/OutputStream from the socket to communicate with the client.
    4. Close Input/OutputStream, Socket and ServerSocket
    5. import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.DataOutputStream;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.net.*;
// a light, on and off
public class TCPServer {
    private ServerSocket server;
    public Thread listener;
    private String host;
    private int port;
    public TCPServer(String host, int port){
        this.host = host;
        this.port = port;
    }
    public boolean start() {
        try{
            server = new ServerSocket(this.port, 10);
            listener = new Thread(()->{
                while(true){
                    Socket worker;
                    try {
                        System.out.println("Waiting client");
                        worker = server.accept();

                        new Thread(()->{
                            try{
                                worker(worker);
                            }catch (IOException e){
                                e.printStackTrace();
                            }
                        }).start();
                    } catch (IOException e) {
                        e.printStackTrace();
                        continue;
                    }
                }
            });
            listener.start();
        }catch (IOException e) {
            System.out.print(e.toString());
            return false;
        }
        return true;
    }
    public void worker(Socket s) throws IOException{
        BufferedReader dataIn = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(s.getInputStream()));
        DataOutputStream dataOut = new DataOutputStream(s.getOutputStream());
        System.out.println("Serving client: " + s.getPort());
        while(true){
            String cmd = dataIn.readLine();
            switch (cmd){
                case "on": System.out.print("Light on"); dataOut.writeByte(1); dataOut.flush();break;
                case "off": System.out.print("Light off"); dataOut.writeByte(1); dataOut.flush();break;
                case "down": System.out.print("disconnect"); dataOut.writeByte(1); dataOut.flush();return;
                default:System.out.print("Unknown cmd: " + cmd); dataOut.writeByte(0); dataOut.flush();return;
            }
        }
    }
    public static void main(String [] args){
        TCPServer server = new TCPServer("localhost", 6655);
        if(!server.start()){
            return;
        }
        System.out.println("Server started");
        try {
            server.listener.join();
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

    }
}

    TCP: Client-side

    1. Socket: client side socket is created by designating host addr and host port, and optional local addr and local port (a client can have multiple network interface).
    2. Get Input/OutputStream from the socket
    3. Close Input/OutputStream, and Socket.
      4. import java.io.*;
import java.net.*;
public class TCPClient {
    public static void main(String [] args) throws IOException, InterruptedException{
        Socket s = new Socket("localhost", 6655);
        DataInputStream dataIn = new DataInputStream(s.getInputStream());
        PrintWriter dataOut = new PrintWriter(new OutputStreamWriter(s.getOutputStream()), true);
        Thread.sleep(1000);
        dataOut.println("on");
        Thread.sleep(1000);
        System.out.println(dataIn.readByte());
        while(true);

    }
}
    4. When one side's writing stream is closed, if the other side is try to read. Then it returns null.

    Network Address

    Address can be represented by a string .e.g "127.0.0.1", "google.com" or by a InetAddress class

    Network address help resolve host name to its real ip address (DNS)

    // obtain ip address of www.sousys.com
import java.net.*;
public class address {
    public static void main(String [] args){
        InetAddress [] addresses;

        try{
            addresses = InetAddress.getAllByName("www.sousys.edu");
        }catch (UnknownHostException e){
            System.out.println(e.toString());
            return;
        }
        for(int i = 0; i < addresses.length; i++){
            printBytes(addresses[i].getAddress());
            System.out.println();
        }
    }
    public static void printBytes(byte [] data){
        if(data == null) return;
        int tmp = 0xff;
        for(int i = 0; i < data.length; i++){
            System.out.print((data[i] & tmp) + "(" + String.format("0x%02X", data[i]) + ") ");
        }
    }
}
